statement:
Let $(M,d)$ be a complete metric space and let
$\psi : M \rightarrow (-\infty, \, +\infty]$,
$\psi \not \equiv +\infty$, be a lower semicontinuous function which is
bounded from below. Then the following hold: For every $\varepsilon > 0$
and for any $z_{0} \in M$ there exists $z \in M$ such that

-   $\psi(z) \leq \psi(z_{0}) - \varepsilon d(z,z_{0})$;

-   $\psi(x) \geq \psi(z) - \varepsilon d(x,z)$, for any $x \in M$.
